bibl.title: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Mary Clayborne Carter, [19--]

div1.p: [Carter] writes Mary Clayborne Carter about Gorgas, the Finlay controversy, and how the discovery of the mosquito as the vector of transmission for yellow fever relied on the work of many contributors.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Mary Clayborne Carter, [19--]
div1.p:
It is Easter Sunday, On the same day of 1920, although it was
in March. I was able to tell Simona Quiroz, at Payta, that bar-
ring accidents, Dr Q., would recover - this being the 6th day of his
fever, I remember her gratitude, as if I had done it! The night before
about 2 P.M. I had gone to see a child of the Alcalde, Franencia
Reygada by name - stopped 3 kind of medicine & removed 4
large mustard plasters & fed her ice until she went to
sleep, I think, maybe, I did save her life, but by what I stopped
rather than by what I did. That isn't long ago. Yet it seems ages
since I boarded the Hullaga at Payta on April 3 the
same year & saw Gorgas for the last time.

Mrs Gorgas returned from Havana Friday where she had
been as the guest 1st of the Am Minister & 2ndof the Presi-
dente. Alfredo Zayas, whom I used to know.

I am glad that Mr. Hendrix accepted some of the quasi sug-
gestions I made in “Gorgas in Habana”. He put in a compli-
ment, to Finlay instead of speaking slightly of him as he
had it. Indeed he left out all of the objectionable parts,
but it still has three fundimantal error's of state-
ment, which I hope will not be in the book.

I made no change in his text, authors are nearly as tem-
premental as Artists (Prima Donnas & c) & I felt sure
that he would not like that. I marked itwith a very soft pen-
cil & very lightly (1): 2: (3) & c & wrote on a separate sheets infor-
mation on the subject of these clauses, marked in th the same
way. So that, he would know what were the facts &
could me could make such changes as thehis [unclear]
added knowledge justified. He readily expunged all ob-
jectionable matter from his paper. Owing
Owing
2m,
Owing to some Rochefeller publication what I don't know
young Carlos Finlay sometime ago wrote a letter to the N.Y. Times
about the refusal of credit to his due his father from the Ar-
my Board, & Mrs Gorgas, says there is a perfect Cult
of F. in Cuba now, leading to a strong Anti-American
feeling. This of course is foolish, yet Finlay did not receive
credit from the Reed Board which was due him, & I sus-
pect that I, myself, in my article on Y. Fever Inin “The
Practice of Medicine in the Tropics” - got out by
the Oxford Press of London &, N York isgave the first on
proper appreciation of Finlay's work in any book,
except by a Cuban, Col Byam, the editor, objected to
putting it in, “as the scheme called for nothing historical”
I advised him, that, “unless this couldcango in, I would ask him
to return the rest of the M.S. also,”

Frankly, I doubt if Finlay's work greatly influenced the direction of
Reed's experiments. He said that they did not in any way. I can
not think this quite true however.

This, the nature of the experiments, (on men) were determined,
by my paper (the one I wrote at North River in the winter of
1898 when Carter and I Chloroformed “Basic” & took the great
splinter out of his foot). This in actis stated by Reed in his first
Report. & is generally accepted by French & British writers &
by the leader's of American Medicine - like Osler, Welche
Thayer & C. Moreover, & of greater importance Iknow it my-
self, & count myself to have been greatly blessed
& am very thankful to God to have had a part and
and an essential part - in a work so beneficial to
men. Of course the beginning of the discovery da-
tes back to Dr. Salmon Chief of the US Vetenarian Bureau
in about 1890-5, then (& to a less extent) to
to McCallough of Hopkins thence Ronald Ross' 1895 to 1898 in India
then myself 18923 to 18899 in the U.S. Finally the Capstone
was put in the arch by Reed 1899-1900. The negative
proof by Gorgas, Cruz: Connor & Hanson & many man since
that date. It is not given to may often given to any
one man to begin & entirely complete a great discov-
ery.

About Fil Finlay I will say this however that if I had, in
1999 read all he had written I would have urged vehe-
mently experiments on men and called for volunteers
to determine the truth of his theory of conveyance

Similarly if I had known of Ross' malaria work, when I pub-
lished my article, (it was sent on in Jan 1999) I would have
claimed definitely instead of suggesting, that y. f & Malaria
were conveyed by the same mechanism - instead of
suggesting that Texas Cattle Fever & Y. F. were convey-
ed the same way. That, R Lazear: Reed: Durham &
Walter Mayer (the last 2 from Liverpool School of Tropical
medince in Havana en route to Para when mayer quickly died
of y. fever) all made this deduction of knowing of Ross's
work, all made this deduction. i.e., “that the mechanism
of the conveyance of Malaria & of y.f. were the same or sim-
ilar”. Shows I think, that a knwith a knowledge of Ross's findings
my work gave the key to the problem & determined the direc-
tion of Reed's experiments, which were absolutely conclu-
sive that y. f. was conveyed from the sick to the well by the
bite of a stegomyia mosquito, itself infected by feeding on the sick
